title: Meteor that hit a home in Georgia is older than Earth, says scientist
description: A meteorite that punched a hole in a Georgia home owner's roof after blazing across the sky in a fiery streak is older than the Earth itself, according to a scientist who examined fragments of the space rock.
content:
A meteorite that punched a hole in a Georgia home owner's roof after blazing across the sky in a fiery streak is older than the Earth itself, according to a scientist who examined fragments of the space rock.

People in several Southern states reported seeing the mysterious fireball in broad daylight on June 26 as it hurtled toward the ground faster than the speed of sound.

University of Georgia planetary geologist Scott Harris said in a press release on Friday that he examined 23 grams (0.8 ounces) of meteorite fragments recovered from a piece the size of a cherry tomato that struck a man's roof like a bullet and left a dent in the floor of the home outside Atlanta.

Examining the fragments under microscopes, Harris concluded the meteorite formed 4.56 billion years ago. That is roughly 20 million years older than the Earth. "It belongs to a group of asteroids in the main asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter that we now think we can tie to a breakup of a much larger asteroid about 470 million years ago, Harris said. Harris said University of Georgia scientists and colleagues at Arizona State University plan to submit their findings with Nomenclature Committee of the Meteoritical Society. They propose naming the space rock the McDonough Meteorite, reflected the name of the Georgia city where it plunged to Earth.
summary: A meteorite that hit a home in Georgia on June 26 is older than the Earth itself, according to a scientist who examined fragments from the space rock. The University of Georgia planetary geologist, Scott Harris, found that the meteorite formed 4.56 billion years ago, roughly 20 million years older than Earth. It is believed to belong to a group of asteroids in the main asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter that scientists believe to have formed from a larger asteroid about 470 million years ago. The researchers propose naming the meteor the McDonough Meteorite, reflecting the name of the Georgia city where it hit.
shortSummary: A meteorite that hit a Georgia home on June 26 was 4.56 billion years old, according to scientists who examined fragments.
argos_summary: A meteorite that struck a Georgia home on June 26 has been found to be older than the Earth, dating back 4.56 billion years. University of Georgia geologist Scott Harris analyzed fragments of the meteorite, which is linked to a larger asteroid breakup that occurred 470 million years ago. The scientists plan to propose naming the meteorite the McDonough Meteorite, after the city where it landed.
